messageBody:
Hello everybody,
this is a late reply to Ian's mail from May. At the time I was just
about to start learning Quikscript and made some notes to myself in
lieu of a reply.
I now finally published those notes on my blog
<http://rethinktheworld.blogspot.com/search/label/quikscript> and I
want to send this to you with my personal history of Quikscript use so
far.
First, I have to say that I was fluently reading and writing English
for a long time without even knowing that its spelling is difficult.
The reason is that I never really spoke the language -- I knew it only
through writing. After I moved to Canada in 2007 I noticed that there
was something wrong with English, but I didn't know what it was. In
2008 I first read about English Spelling Reform and I instantly knew
that I would have to investigate this further and find one reform
proposal that would work for me. I finally took the time to
investigate all those proposals last winter (ironically that was when
I studied Chinese in Taiwan). I found that Quikscript is by far the
best proposal on how to practically write English and decided to learn
it as soon as I would go back to Canada.

Now I have learned Quikscript, I am using it to write my diary, for
shopping lists, and other handwritten notes. Quikscript has helped me
already to improve my pronunciation and to gain back respect for
English as a language! Once I can write it properly, English becomes a
language of its own, instead of a mix of Old Germanic, French, and
Latin, all weirdly pronounced.
Obviously, the benefits of a simplified spelling are much less for
people who have already wasted many years in school to learn the
complicated spelling and who master it quite well. Quikscript will be
most beneficial for people that haven't learned to write yet, that is,
children and non-native speakers. I think that both groups can benefit
much from learning Quikscript, even if they also have to learn the
current English writing with the Latin alphabet. I think that the
future of Quikscript lies in the people who will learn both writing
systems; Quikscript first; and who will invariably feel that
Quikscript is the true written version of the English language, while
the traditional spelling is just a way to communicate with people who
haven't learned this proper way.
My children will definitely be fluent readers and writers of
Quikscript before they start going to school. Being able to express
their language visually will make it easier for them to memorize the
arcane rules and exceptions of traditional spelling. (Just as most
foreigners use IPA or some other means of writing the pronunciation of
words to make language learning easier.)

Personally, my next step is now to become fluent in reading Quikscript
and to develop a consistent and clear accent (or non-accent) for
speaking and writing.

that's my two (Euro-)cents so far,
Jack
